descriptions.symptoms: Small, circular to elongate, reddish-brown pustules (uredinia) on both leaf surfaces. As the disease progresses, pustules may turn black (telia). Severe infections can cause leaf yellowing and premature leaf senescence.
descriptions.conditions: Cool, moderate temperatures (60-77°F) with high humidity and extended leaf wetness favor the disease.
descriptions.pathogen: Caused by the fungus Puccinia sorghi.

treatments.Resistant Varieties: Plant corn hybrids with resistance to common rust.
treatments.Fungicides: Apply foliar fungicides if the disease appears early and weather conditions favor its spread. Fungicides like strobilurins (e.g., azoxystrobin) and triazoles (e.g., propiconazole) are effective.
treatments.Crop Rotation and Residue Management: Rotate crops to reduce the inoculum in the field and manage crop residues to minimize overwintering spores.

descriptions.symptoms: Lesions start as small, necrotic spots that expand into rectangular, gray to tan lesions parallel to leaf veins. Severe infections can lead to extensive leaf blighting and reduced photosynthetic area.
descriptions.conditions: Warm, humid weather with prolonged periods of leaf wetness promotes the disease.
descriptions.pathogen: Caused by the fungus Cercospora zeae-maydis.

treatments.Resistant Varieties: Use hybrids that have partial resistance to gray leaf spot.
treatments.Fungicides: Apply fungicides like strobilurins (e.g., pyraclostrobin) and triazoles (e.g., propiconazole) at tasseling or early silking if the disease pressure is high.
treatments.Crop Rotation and Tillage: Rotate crops and till the soil to reduce the amount of infected crop residue.

descriptions.symptoms: No symptoms present. The plant exhibits normal growth and development.
descriptions.conditions: Optimal growing conditions with proper management practices.

treatments.Good Agricultural Practices: Maintain good agricultural practices such as crop rotation, proper irrigation, and balanced fertilization to keep plants healthy.

descriptions.symptoms: Large, elongated, cigar-shaped gray-green or tan lesions on leaves. Severe infections can cause extensive leaf blighting, resulting in premature death and yield loss.
descriptions.conditions: Moderate to warm temperatures (64-81°F) with high humidity or frequent rain favor disease development.
descriptions.pathogen: Caused by the fungus Exserohilum turcicum.

treatments.Resistant Varieties: Choose hybrids with genetic resistance to northern leaf blight.
treatments.Fungicides: Use fungicides such as strobilurins (e.g., azoxystrobin) and triazoles (e.g., tebuconazole) at early signs of disease or when conditions are favorable for disease development.
treatments.Crop Rotation and Residue Management: Practice crop rotation and manage crop residues through tillage to reduce the pathogen load.

descriptions.symptoms: Small, dark brown to black lesions on leaves, often with concentric rings giving a target-like appearance. Lesions can also appear on stems and tubers.
descriptions.conditions: Warm temperatures (75-85°F) and high humidity or frequent rain.
descriptions.pathogen: Caused by the fungus Alternaria solani.

treatments.Resistant Varieties: Plant potato varieties with resistance to early blight.
treatments.Fungicides: Apply fungicides such as chlorothalonil or mancozeb at regular intervals, starting before symptoms appear.
treatments.Crop Rotation and Sanitation: Rotate crops and remove infected plant debris to reduce the source of inoculum.

descriptions.symptoms: No symptoms present. The plant exhibits normal growth and development.
descriptions.conditions: Optimal growing conditions with proper management practices.

treatments.Good Agricultural Practices: Maintain good agricultural practices such as crop rotation, proper irrigation, and balanced fertilization to keep plants healthy.

descriptions.symptoms: Water-soaked, pale green to dark brown lesions on leaves and stems. Lesions may have a yellow halo and can rapidly expand, leading to plant collapse. Tubers can develop firm, brown, granular lesions.
descriptions.conditions: Cool, moist conditions with temperatures between 50-60°F and high humidity.
descriptions.pathogen: Caused by the oomycete Phytophthora infestans.

treatments.Fungicides: Apply fungicides such as metalaxyl or mandipropamid at regular intervals, especially during favorable conditions for the disease.
treatments.Crop Rotation and Sanitation: Practice crop rotation and remove and destroy infected plant debris to reduce inoculum sources.

descriptions.symptoms: Small, circular to oval brown spots with gray or whitish centers on leaves, stems, and grains. Severe infections can cause significant yield loss.
descriptions.conditions: High humidity, warm temperatures (77-82°F), and poor soil fertility.
descriptions.pathogen: Caused by the fungus Bipolaris oryzae.

treatments.Fungicides: Apply fungicides such as tricyclazole or propiconazole during early stages of disease development.
treatments.Nutrient Management: Ensure balanced soil fertility, particularly with adequate levels of potassium and phosphorus.

descriptions.symptoms: No symptoms present. The plant exhibits normal growth and development.
descriptions.conditions: Optimal growing conditions with proper management practices.

treatments.Good Agricultural Practices: Maintain good agricultural practices such as crop rotation, proper irrigation, and balanced fertilization to keep plants healthy.

descriptions.symptoms: Spindle-shaped lesions with gray centers and brown margins on leaves. Severe infections can lead to leaf death and significant yield loss.
descriptions.conditions: High humidity, frequent rainfall, and temperatures between 77-86°F.
descriptions.pathogen: Caused by the fungus Magnaporthe oryzae.

treatments.Fungicides: Apply fungicides such as tricyclazole or isoprothiolane at early stages of disease development.
treatments.Water Management: Avoid excessive irrigation and maintain proper water levels to reduce humidity around plants.

descriptions.symptoms: Lesions on the neck of the panicle, causing it to break and resulting in grain loss. Infected grains may turn white or gray and be unfilled.
descriptions.conditions: High humidity, frequent rainfall, and temperatures between 77-86°F.
descriptions.pathogen: Caused by the fungus Magnaporthe oryzae.

treatments.Fungicides: Apply fungicides such as tricyclazole or isoprothiolane at the booting stage of rice growth.
treatments.Water Management: Avoid excessive irrigation and maintain proper water levels to reduce humidity around plants.

descriptions.symptoms: Small, circular to oval orange-brown pustules (uredinia) on leaves and stems. Severe infections can lead to leaf death and reduced grain fill.
descriptions.conditions: Cool temperatures (59-72°F) and high humidity or prolonged leaf wetness.
descriptions.pathogen: Caused by the fungus Puccinia recondita.

treatments.Resistant Varieties: Plant wheat varieties with resistance to brown rust.
treatments.Fungicides: Apply fungicides such as propiconazole or tebuconazole at the first sign of disease or when conditions are favorable for disease development.
treatments.Crop Rotation and Residue Management: Practice crop rotation and manage crop residues to reduce the inoculum load.

descriptions.conditions: Optimal growing conditions with proper management practices.

descriptions.symptoms: Small, yellow pustules (uredinia) that form in stripes on leaves and stems. Severe infections can lead to leaf death and reduced grain fill.
descriptions.pathogen: Caused by the fungus Puccinia striiformis.

treatments.Resistant Varieties: Plant wheat varieties with resistance to yellow rust.
treatments.Fungicides: Apply fungicides such as propiconazole or tebuconazole at the first sign of disease or when conditions are favorable for disease development.
treatments.Crop Rotation and Residue Management: Practice crop rotation and manage crop residues to reduce the inoculum load.
